Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2015 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Daniel Litt is "Algebraic Geometry." The host institution for the fellowship is Columbia University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Johan de Jong.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to study interactions between algebraic geometry and number theory, primarily through various incarnations of the fundamental group of an algebraic variety. Loosely speaking, the fundamental group of a space carries information about loops in that space -- if the space is of number-theoretic interest, then one can hope to recover number-theoretic information from this geometric data.

The project resulted in nine publications, five of which have been published and three of which have been submitted for publication. The intellectual merit of these publications is contained in their answers to important open mathematical questions -- in particular, the publications "Arithmetic representations of fundamental groups I" and "Arithmetic representations of fundamental groups II" contain new tools to apply the arithmetic of fundamental groups to open questions about monodromy representations, which I anticipate will have important applications in future years. More broadly, the techniques developed in these papers will help mathematicians answer number-theoretic questions via geometric techniques. Broadly, the goal of number theory is to detect rational solutions to systems of polynomial equations -- these papers open a window into how to answer these sorts of basic questions by studying the geometry of the *shapes* defined by these polynomial equations. The other research work produced while supported by the fellowship included applications of arithmetic techniques to understanding the geometry of shapes defined by polynomial equations -- in particular, questions as to how to understand the geometry of a high-dimensional shape from its cross-sections.

Broader impacts of the project include: mentoring two individual undergraduate research projects and three group undergraduate research projects, as well as broad dissemination of mathematics in the form of papers, and more than 50 research talks at conferences and in seminars. The project also supported outreach efforts to a broader audience, including a Numberphile video on Youtube (explaining a mathematical object called the Dehn invariant) which as of this writing has more than 300,000 views, as well as several talks aimed at high school and middle school students about research in mathematics and the history of certain mathematical problems arising from cosmology.
